title: Finger print setting disappeared from my next-bit robin

thread.text:
I am Shocked, suddenly fingerprint setting disappeared from my nexbit robin,
please any body help how can i get it back.

I'm debating what my next phone is going to be. I have an HTC M7 and it's still running good but the battery is starting to go so I'm looking to get a replacement. I like the size and feel of this phone, I'm not looking for a phablet. HTC 10 is not is an option as it's just too expensive, even with the discount is still $600. I can get the 6P for a good price, they have sales seemingly every other month. I'm concerned about it's size.. So it's kind of between the Robin and One+3. Any thoughts

replies.text:
Since you said that you don't want a phablet, the 6p might be really annoying for you.
The Robin and the 1+3 are both good in their own right. What are some of the most important things that you would like to have in a phone, aside from size?
I have the Nextbit Robin curremtly and I'm liking it, but if you can answer that question for me, that would help me to help you.
Both the Nextbit OS and Oxygen OS are nice and fairly close to Nexus level, but 1+3's OS (oxygen) has some more add-ons.

Nice job rocking an M7 for so long! Besides my Pre 2, and probably even more than that, the M7 is my favorite phone. I only made it until the spring of 2015 before I switched. I got my wife and mother in law the Robin last month and while my mother in law hasn't used it yet, my wife loves hers coming from an iphone 5s. For $120 now the phones are a great deal.

thread.text: I have concerns about the battery life and how well the cloud storage works. What if you need an app or photo and you are not in a good wifi or cell area. What happens? Are you sol until you get a good signal? Does the battery last a whole day on moderate use? How is the build quality of the phone?

replies.text:
Out the box, the battery life of the Robin doesn't last a day with my experience. Maybe 12 hours at most. With tweaks, I get a day and some. As for the cloud storage, I disabled it so I can't answer. I do know that cloud backup only happens when you are on wifi and plugged in. There was an issue with the paint chipping on the Midnight one but that has been fixed. Some have reported having the device can slightly bend, but I haven't had this issue.
Since the size is a true concern for you, I would recommend ordering a Robin from Amazon who allows returns. Out of your choices, I have to be honest and say that the camera on the Robin is weaker than the other two.

thread.text: I'd get the OnePlus 3 over Robin due to better build quality. You could also wait to see if the Nexus Marlin and Sailfish by HTC are better options.
Excellent, thank you.
My Robin is a nice phone, but the build quality is on the weaker side of things.

I have been using a 6P for about a year now and I can say without any caveats that it is by far the best phone that I have ever owned. I also just bought my wife a Nexbit Robin when they were on sale at Amazon recently. Which so far from what I have seen, it is a very nice device. It seems very smooth and I honestly love the unusual design and UI. The camera is definitely a step down from her old phone but it is still good enough for what she uses it for. Also for her the battery doesn't quite make it through the day, but she uses her phones pretty heavily. For example she used to have a Galaxy S6 with a 3500mah battery case that wouldn't make it through the day either. So it's hard to beat up the robin too much based on her usage. Especially considering the internal battery alone is lasting about as long or even a little longer than the Samsung + external battery did.
However performance wise the Robin can't come close to matching the 6P. Yes the 6P is a little on the large side, but once you get used to it, it's not bad. Although honestly if there were one thing I could change about it, it would still be to make it smaller, because it is larger than I really like. However the benefits of the 6P are that it has a stellar camera, a very fast processor, decent battery life and it is going to get system updates much faster and for a longer time, than anything else out there. 
Personally my opinion is that if the price is not a factor for any of these phones get the 6P, it's definitely worth the premium. However if you want to save a few dollars and don't mind a slightly slower but more quirky and interesting device the Robin is not a bad choice either. It is a very good midrange device just don't expect the performance of a flagship phone. 
Honestly I haven't used a One+ phone so I cannot personally recommend or detract from it, but if I had to guess it would probably slot somewhere in between the 6P and Robin in terms of features specs and price and might be a decent compromise between the two. 
Also since you are looking don't forget to look at the Nexus 5X. Performance wise it basically has the same specs as the Robin, but with the same camera sensor and system updates as the 6P, and in a smaller package. Honestly we had originally planned on getting my wife a 5X, but when the Robin went on sale it was just such a great deal it was hard to pass it up, plus she just really liked the styling of the Robin.

I went with robin, picked up a brand new one from Mercari for $240. So far I'm loving it, no android phone has ever had this kind looky lu effect. Every time someone sees my mint robin they ask what kind of phone is that and it's so awesome. I haven't used the cloud feature yet and I'm running Nova launcher on it. Battery life has not been an issue for me, I'm not a heavy user. I bought the Robin quick charger directly from Nextbit and that has been working great. It charges the phone from 10% to 100% in about an hour and 15 minutes. So far so good with the Robin.

I ruled out the Nexus 5X because I've heard it had so may problems, it looks like they've fixed all those issues with updates but I didn't want to deal with it. Not to mention limited to 32gb and no sd card. I know the Robin doesn't have sd card either but I can always upload my photos and videos to the cloud, 100GB worth if need be. Also, I just like the like the look of the Robin, I've never been a big fan of LG.I think LG's phones are as boring as iphones.
You can get a sweet deal on a Le Eco Pro 3...under $300, Snap 821, 4 gb ram, 1080 5.5 display. Use the google launcher app for a near stock experience. My son loves his.

title: How long do you get to keep the cloud storage?

thread.text: do you get to keep it for good? Any deadlines on when the service ends?
Nextbit said they would continue support the phone until 2/2018 so my guess would be then. I can't find anything official though about the storage though.

title: nextbit robin screen wont turn and not charging....

thread.text:
My Robin phone is unable to boot up. My Robin has just went into "Black Screen" mode, with no charging light indication and no display stating the phone is undergoing charging. Yesterday, my Robin is "Black Screen" when My Robin phone charged overnight.
I try these methods, but my phone still "Black Screen" mode and unsuccessful
try booting into fastboot mode. volume down + power
change the new type-c cable
check the nextbit charger that still normally operate
Please help me! Thank you!

Welcome to Android Central! Uh-oh, the battery or motherboard may have failed. Is it still under warranty? Given that support for the Robin is winding down, I'm not sure you'll have much luck with Razer/Nextbit -- you may just have to bring it to a repair shop.
no-one wants to repair my phone..i don't know why...but is there anyway to check the battery is working or not...

title: Problem with updating Nextbit robin from Android 7.0 to Android 7.1.1

thread.text: It shows there is an official update for Android 7.1.1, and it has downloaded and verified. When I click on restart and install, it starts the countdown "Rebooting in x seconds". Nothing happens after countdown
Moved to the Nextbit Robin forum.

Anyone got a spare Nextbit Robin replacement SIM tray or know where I can find one?
Thanks!
Try eBay or do any internet search places have them.
Thanks, done that before posting, no luck..

I'm going to be getting a new phone here soon, and so far none of the releases look interesting and with Samsung going to all curved glass is the nextbit worth buying in 2017 to get me to next year or maybe a little after?

Depends what you're looking for  I just took the plunge and I'm totally excited with a phone so unique and doing its own thing. Being it's supposed to have support until Feb 2018, you should be good  For the price (got mine for 149), it's hard to beat, really.

Thanks I find it interesting also and was considering either it or the Nexus 5x but I'm thinking at 149 I am gonna go after it also I really like the style they went with what color did you end up getting?

Yeah, they're pretty similar in specs (Robin has 3GB RAM vs Nexus 2GB). I went with mint. It wasn't an easy choice, but the mint just seemed more "robin" like! I also ordered the midnight bruises case, so it's kinda like having the best of both, in a way.  Either color is really pretty, though. I just thought mint was more unique.

OP, if you're choosing between the 5X and the Robin, the Robin is a better performer. The 5X does have the better camera and fingerprint scanner, but it isn't aging as well from what I've heard.
Robin looks nice...I own the mint one. If you can get the red + black or the red + yellow models (both are hard to find), that's as unique as the mint.

Thanks for response, I think I have planned on getting Robin to get me through atleast this year. Especially after seeing what Samsung is putting out (I hate curved screens) I have pretty much ruled out every big name this release cycle.
OP, you want one new, mint or used? I may be willing to part with my used one at a decent price (especially if you are in the US).

As someone who as owned this phone for awhile, if price is a factor of the purchase, the phone is good for the price. However, if you want a quality phone, consider waiting a few weeks/months as there are a few phones coming out after Google I/O. I like (but not love)my Robin as it was a good phone for the price. There is now a warp on the frame as it was a plastic phone with a metal frame that is normal (or so Robin claimed when I contacted them). So my phone rocks slightly as the frame has warpped in the first few months, but the over feel/working of the phone has been acceptible.
I have mint Robin and I love it, it's not the most powerful phone but its still running well and I can't get over how unique it is. All of the other designs look boring in comparison.

Ordered mine yesterday, Mint, and will receive it today. Got the Amazon Prime sale of $118. My Nexus 5 is on its last legs and I couldn't afford a new phone, so getting this for such a steal will tide me over for quite some time. And it will have 7.1.1 plus security patches through February 2018.
I had been looking at the Robin pretty much since release but as noted couldn't afford a new phone plus my Nexus was fine at the time. Completely psyched to be getting it now.

For the bargain price of around 120 it's a no brainier if you need a cheap fast phone, not to mention it has the latest nougat and NFC. The build is all plastic though and keep it mind all warranty and support has but cut off from the company after being taken over by Razer.

Received my Mint Robin couple of weeks ago and I'm loving it. Had a Nexus 6 but just too big! I use it to make short demo videos for our clients. Nexus was always fine but Robin audio sounds like it's under water. I think it's an encoding issue. I have tried many different apps with no success. I love Cinema FV5 but can't get good audio. Camera photos are fine, Camera FV5 is my favorite.
Can someone please suggest a cure for the audio?
Thanks!

Welcome to Android Central! Just to be sure -- have you checked the secondary mic opening to make sure it isn't clogged by lint or other debris? Also, if you use speakerphone to call someone, does the other person also think you sound like you're underwater?

Hi, the 2 mic opening are on top and on the bottom, correct? Both clear 
Speakerphone is perfectly clear both directions. Speakers sound great for podcasts, YouTube, music fine. Monitoring the audio on headphones is fine. It's just the resulting audio on the recording that is bad. It's the same poor quality you get when ripping a DVD with Handbrake. It seems to be a problem with the encoder.
You may be right. This might be worth a call or email to Nextbit support: https://help.nextbit.com/hc/en-us

Hi everybody,
I have Huawei nova plus and experiencing same problems. I just can't stend the audio quality on my recorded videos. It has some kind of background noise reduction or something which makes the audio of videos very awful. 
thanks in advance.

Any of you guys in the beta program. Have you gotten the Nougat beta yet? How's it running? 
I'm downloading the update now. I'll post back to let you know how it's going.
How do you enroll in the beta program?

replies.text:
🗽Welcome to ACentral : Review this AC-Tech article..to find 
the "Know how" to enroll as Beta tester in Android OS
Link: How to enroll in the Android Beta Program | Android Central..
that is for nexus phones and nexbit is not a nexus phone nexbit they will have there own beta programe if they have one

title: B&H Photo now sells the Nextbit Robin

thread.text: Found this while browsing around the site. Very cool! Not sure why one is more than the other though.https://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/searc...100+3602808655

Has the Robin been keeping up with the monthly Google security updates?
Are they promising Nougat anytime soon?
They don't do updates monthly, they do it every other month. When I had a Robin, the security update available when the update is released has been included in it.

Thanks. Good to know. Getting my wife something new in the near future and the Robin as well as the N5x are in the running. She's coming from a N5 and wants something close to that size. I was waiting to see how much the Pixel was going to cost but it's obviously in a whole different place now.
Anyone who has had both have any opinions?

title: How are you liking your Robin?

thread.text: I just spent my first full weekend with my Robin and I have to say, I'm quite impressed. The camera is definitely alright and the battery held up each day. So far my only complaint is that my USB cable is garbage and I'm having to use the one from my 950.

I'm really liking mine so far as well. I was initially worried with performance, but haven't really got any hiccups yet. I admit I haven't taken many photos yet, but the ones I have aren't bad at all.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Agreed - the thing is lightning fast... except the camera app. But the camera isn't as poor as most people made it out to be. 
It was mentioned somewhere that they're speeding up the camera app in the next update, so we have that to look forward to as well.

thread.text:
Just received mine this week. Darn what a great product. My friends are asking what type of phone is that is really elegant looking. Midnight blue is the color I have. Some new software updates I see are heading our way soon!
Posted via the Android Central App
Yeah! I love the phone. It gets a ton of attention. And I'm not missing the app drawer as much as I thought I would.

I hope you don't mind me using this thread for first impressions and later edit or type a new response.
First impressions: 
This device is huge. I normally use an iPhone SE so yeah.
I love the colors and design of this phone. Green!!
Also really liking the launcher.
Whoa the sound is probably one of the best I have ever heard on a phone.
The power button is really flush against the phone.
I didn't know what to expect for the corners but the corners don't feel sharp in the hand.
I just set it up last night so that is all for now.
Final impressions:
I no longer have this phone.
Loved the look and the concept but had to return it after dealing with it being stuck in airplane mode.
Not interested in doing a factory reset every time this happens.
Posted via the Android Central App

Just got mine during the Amazon sale and so far I'm very happy with it! The build and hand feel are surprisingly good, the tastefully done UI is the first android skin I've liked in a long time. 
My timing was also good because of the recent updates, and I think the speakers sound excellent, and the camera, while not up there with the leaders, is solid.
So, first impressions are very positive, we'll see how it goes over the next few weeks. 
Posted via the Android Central App

I couldn't pass up 100 dollars off either!  Mine is coming tomorrow, well I guess later today since it's after midnight here, lol! Had I ordered it 1 hour earlier I could have even gotten it already with same day shipping! lol

I really like mine; two gripes though.
1) Wish it had double tap to wake.
2) The speakers are too loud with the latest update.

replies.text:
You aren't serious about number 2 are you or are you saying the speakers distort?
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
Actually I think I just figured out what you are talking about. I just played a couple of YouTube videos and it was too loud on its lowest setting. This is only the second day I have had it and I didn't listen to it prior to the update. This will be very annoying in situations where you are in a very quiet environment and want or need a low volume and level one sounds like level 5 on other phones.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: I agree about this. Someone posted a temporary fix on the Nextbit forums. Install DSP Manager Lite and save a preset to fix the sound thing. Moving all of the things to the left would adjust the sound to be the way you want it to be. I did that myself. Let me take a screenshot and add it to this post on mobile.

thread.text:
Happy to find out it will be fixed on the next update, but its hard to fathom how the last update was released with this oversight.
Posted via the Android Central App

Sorry to double post but it wouldn't let me add the image to my last post.
Posted via the Android Central App

The loudness of of the device is not the issue for me, it's great, however, when I place the volume at the lowest possible setting, it is still really loud. At least on my unit, after the update, there is not a big difference between the volume settings. It's loud, or really loud to the point where the sounds starts to crack.

replies.text: I agree. I like the DSP but I think I will only use that when I plan to listen to audio. It being on ALL the time is a serious battery drain. I'm on my 2nd full day, (it's been 3 1/4 days now) and I need to see how the battery is without that running and draining the battery noticeably enough.

thread.text:
I've had it for four days. Fantastic phone so far!
Posted via the Android Central App

Okay, so I felt like I should adjust/update my impressions. I was really disappointed that the Robin was stuck in airplane mode, and I felt so cheated of wanting to try it. Of course, I returned it and got my money back. Then it went on sale recently and since I felt the way I did, I decided to give it a second try.
(Whoops, didn't mean for it to be this long)
The tl;dr version:
-Liking almost everything about this device, including that VoLTE and Band 12 on T-Mo.
-Not liking daily charging and the MMS not working with WiFi connected
-My dislikes are so annoying that it has me debating if I want to keep this
The long version:
Thankfully this try is better. It's been 4 days and I find that I am mostly liking it a lot. It's actually making me rethink how I view Android. Really a fan of the UI. I'm satisfied with the camera and the speakers. I did install the DSP Lite thing that I suggested upthread but I decided not to use it anymore because it drains the battery. My workaround for now is to set the volume at low (it's not really so low but eh). Call volume is pretty good on speaker and in general.
I'm on T-Mobile, so the VoLTE and Band 12 was a super important thing for me to have or else I would have passed on this device (more so the latter thing and not the former though). My work kind of sucks for reception big time, so WiFi calling was important and I was nervous about this. At work, I have not lost reception once. 
The Robin has been mostly pleasant, my only issues are the following two things:
-Battery life. I have had to charge my Robin every day, and I don't really like that. Coming from the SE which I charge every other day, this is a huge adjustment. If there's something I can do about this, I would be open to hearing it, but I'll rather not flash another ROM.
-MMS issue with WiFi connected. This seems to be a issue for not just me. I randomly get MMS (from my friends, coworkers, and sis, but my coworkers are the most likely, more so group texts over images though). The scary thing about this is that I wouldn't even know if I have a MMS until I toggle the WiFi off. Luckily, I have 10gb of data but this is annoying for sure.
So I'm on the fence about keeping this for my two annoyances mainly. Generally though, I enjoy the sound, the UI/launcher, camera, and of course, the look of the phone.

replies.text:
I'm glad you gave it a second chance! Yeah, battery life is a solid day. I'm running CM 13 on it now and it's vastly improved my battery life, but how I use the phone, it's definitely a solid day and night out (which I rarely do) and no more. Plus, if you don't want to Rom your phone, that's no option anyway.
I was also having mms issues before and now no longer. There are some things cm isn't good at, but they did fix the things Nextbit was bad at.
Posted via the Android Central App

Thank you, me too! Really didn't think that I would enjoy it so much, never saw myself enjoying an Android phone this much.
Ah dang, the fact that this fixed both things has me curious now. 
VoLTE is too valuable for me though to lose. Even so, I'm curious what things you say that CM isn't good at though.
Edit: Someone posted a workaround for the MMS thing on the Nextbit forums that actually isn't too bad, and it seems to work for now.

Eh, basically what's not great about CM is stability. Things crash from time-to-time. I have found that Google Now, Chrome, and the Swype are affected the most. I haven't tried other keyboards yet since it's intermittent, but it has been a minor annoyance. I should try others.
I don't know how CM does so much better asleep than the Nextbit software with regards to the battery.
Also, CM now updates OTA for nightly builds. Updating the build is cake and you can do it every day if you want! Ha

thread.text: I got one off of Amazon when they were having the $100 off. I like it as it is nice and fast and the feel in my hand is nice. So far, so good on my experience with it so far.

My wife has one in Midnight. She loves it compared to the LG G4 she had before. Her biggest gripe right now is battery life. She gets about 3/4 of a day before she has to charge it. I installed Sound Profiler to control the loud audio problem.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Yeah the battery life is the only thing that annoyed me about it. I'm too used to phones that give me a day and some of battery life.
Sent from mTalk

thread.text: So I couldn't let go, ended up buying another Robin to keep. Making tweaks for the battery life makes me like it so much more now. No more fast charge in the morning and running to a charger in the evening, thankfully. I get about 20-24 hours of usage (so literally about a day) which is something I can deal with.
what tweaks did you do?

replies.text: I did a couple of things, I'll just quote my post:I also have Wifi to not be connected when the phone is sleeping but you don't have to do that. I only do that because my wifi at work is so varied. Since I have been doing this, I always get at least 20 hours on one charge. 20 hours is with me using it a lot and I can't put it down unless I'm sleeping or really busy with work or doing something that I need serious focus for. In actuality, it's more like near 23-24 hours. I'm just someone who generally charges on 30 something percent, so generally a day and some is what I get.

thread.text:
International version of Nextbit Robin
Use in Hong Kong since 2 weeks ago.
Pros:
- headphone jack audio is great, IMHO
- unique design
- no bloatware
- fingerprint censor is fast and responsive
- latest June security patches are available
Cons:
- process intensive apps cause the phone hot on both sides
Other (not a complain):
- Octopus apps does not support the phone (Hong Kong provider issue)
- not able to play .ts file due to codecs missing
Overall the OS is solid and lightweight. It would be nice if we can have control over the cloud storage. It gives you choices and allows user to install other OS (i.e. CM, AOSP).

title: Cyanogen Mod 13 for the Nextbit Robin

thread.text:
Guys! You can download and install CM13 on the Nextbit Robin. It's a bit of a process, but if you want, here is what I had to do on my Windows 10 PC:
First you'll want to ready your computer:
1) Download and install the USB Drivers for the Nextbit Robin
2) Download and install ADB and Fastboot
3) Download TWRP Recovery
4) Download the newest CM13 nightly ROM
5) Rename the TWRP download to twrp.img and the CM13 download to cm.zip and make sure you know where they are
6) Download your preferred gapps package (google apps) Pick ARM64 in the first column, 6.0 in the second, and decide which version in the third
Now you need to ready your phone:
1) Go to Settings>About Phone and find the build number. Tap on that a bunch (I think it's 7 times to be exact) until it congratulates you on being a developer
2) Go to Settings>Developer options and toggle on/active Android debugging (or ADB)
3) In Settings>Developer options there should also be a toggle to allow bootloader unlocking. Make sure that's on/active as well
We have both devices ready. At this point, connect your Nextbit to your computer. You should get prompted on your phone on whether or not you want to allow your computer to access your phone. I've found that it's best to check the box to always allow and allow the computer access to the phone. Now we can send commands to your Nextbit from the command line using ADB.
Now, with your Nextbit connected to your computer, open the folder on your computer that has the file twrp.img. Hold control and right click in this window; this should allow you to open a command prompt in this folder. WARNING: THE NEXT STEPS WILL WIPE YOUR DEVICE - MAKE SURE IMPORTANT FILES ARE BACKED UP
Now in the command prompt type: ADB reboot bootloader
You'll see your device reboot into the bootloader. It should be in fastboot mode by default
Once the device installs, in the same command prompt type: fastboot -i 0x2c3f oem unlock
It should give you a warning at this point that you're going to wipe everything and whatnot. If you want an unlocked bootloader, agree.
It will wipe everything and you'll have a Robin that feels brand new, but the bootloader will be unlocked.Congrats! You've unlocked your bootloader! Now we'll work on the custom recovery.
1) Once your Robin has booted, we need to get back to the bootloader screen if we're not there. Press and hold the volume down and power button together. This should force the phone to shut down. Once it's shut down, release the power button while holding the volume down button and then press it again to turn the device on and into the bootloader. It should be in fastboot mode by default.
2) Since we still have the command window open and since we opened it in the folder that had the twrp.img file in it, we can right away type the command: fastboot -i 0x2c3f flash recovery twrp.img
3) Reboot the bootloader in whichever way feels best for you
4) Navigate to recovery using the volume keys and use the power button to boot into the recovery *note: if you aren't at a screen that says something about TeamWin, you're in the wrong place. I had to repeat steps 1-3 to achieve this. Not sure why, but it fixed it for me.Congrats! You now have a custom recovery installed on your Robin. Now we'll install the Cyanogen rom.This is where we're most likely to wreck everything. Be careful.
In the Team Win Recovery it will first ask you for a decryption password. I couldn't, for the life of me, figure out what they were asking for. I canceled out of the whole thing. It should then ask if you are going to want to modify the system partition. You have to swipe the slider along the bottom to allow this. Note: the way I'm going to install the rom is pretty risky since we don't have the option to backup before we wipe and install. Nextbit has made a tool that probably does a lot of the work that we've done automatically. It's a huge file, so I opted to not download it, but it should recover your phone should we get into trouble. 
Now that we have that out of the way, let's get installing.
1) Tap Mount and make sure System, Data, and Cache are selected.
2) Return to the TWRP home screen
3) Tap Wipe
4) Tap Advanced Wipe
5) Select Dalvic, System, Data, and Cache
6) Swipe to Wipe at the bottom
7) Return homeAt this point, we've gotten rid of our Nextbit rom and the encryption so we can see the storage and install new things
8) Tap mount again
9) In the bottom right tap to Enable MTP
10) On your computer now, you should be able to see your Robin under My Computer. Open up internal storage.
11) Copy both cm.zip and your gapps package into internal storage
12) On your phone, return home
13) Tap Install
14) Click the top option "Up a Level" until it disappears
15) Find the folder that is named "sdcard" and go into it. This is where your rom and google apps are
16) Select cm.zip and swipe to confirm flash
17) Wipe cacheAt this point, you have CM13 installed! Now we need the google apps so you have the full Android experience
18) Install gapps the same way you installed the cm.zip
19) Wipe cache
20) Go home, tap the reboot button, and reboot systemCongrats!!! You've done it!! You've installed Cyanogen mod on your Nextbit Robin! Set it up and let it rip! This process should be the same for any rom you can download.
Hope that was clear. Feel free to ask questions if something wasn't quite right!

Thanks !!!
Posted via the Android Central App
Also, this should work for any rom.zip file you'd want to install.

Finally after looking for all sorts od devices I ordered the midnight Robin yesterday. Being a phone addictive gone through. A lot of devices in the last couple of years (blackberry z30,leap,priv,passport, sony xperia, Microsoft lumia 640 and 950)
Dont like android much, but the looks of robin made me order one.
How long does it take to get it shipped to canada? Hopefully its not a long wait

replies.text:
May be a good idea to contact the site you purchased it from. Or at least provide WHERE you bought it from if you are looking for this answer.
I am assuming Amazon. And if it was Amazon, then it depends on how you choose to ship it. It's pretty clear on their site
Want it Monday, June 27? Order within 20 hrs 18 mins and choose Two-Day Shipping at checkout.
If you didn't choose that option I am sure it would have given you a time frame for shipping...
On the Nextbit forums, I saw someone say 2 weeks. One week to ship, another week to get it. At least from them directly. Unless you ordered from Amazon, that is.

thread.text:
I ordered mine directly from Nextbit (midnight) Monday night (20th) and received it the 24th. I'm also located in Canada. Will most likely arrive with FedEx.
On a side note, your device history is interesting. I'm curious as to why you didn't like the Priv? I've had Z10 before upgrading to a Passport. I was eyeing the Priv but simply could not justify the price for the similar specs as the Robin. Still adapting to the Android world coming from BB10 but overall I'm enjoying it. Hope you get your device soon!

replies.text:
I bought the priv when it was released and I was still missing bb10. Plus I don't use physical keyboard at all. Hence I retuned it.
Now its come to a full circle. After using windows mobile for a while I do miss the apps adn the windows OS have bugs and lags at times. Ready to give a Android another go
Sent from mTalk

thread.text:
Ordered on Friday and got my package today - tuesday morning. Super excited. Will open and set ut up tonight.
Sent from mTalk

replies.text: It sounds like you and me are in a similar situation. Enjoy your Robin!! The Robin is the one of the few Android phones I really liked a lot. I'm willing to keep with Android, as long as I can do it with the Robin. What color did you order?

thread.text:
Midnight blue.
How long have u had yours?
How do u like android and robin so far? How's the overall performance? Battery life?
Sent from mTalk

replies.text:
Nice!
There's a story behind why I am waiting for another one but most recently a week. 
Android is okay, there's a slight learning curve and I did a lot of googling on how to do some stuff. Unlike Windows Phone/Mobile, I feel like it takes more steps to do some things. It's kind of cool, but slightly overwhelming that you can change default apps, like the web browser, phone, and sms/messaging.
The overall performance is pretty good (I'll give it a 7 out of 10). The cameras are decent, battery life on the other hand, I have gotten less than a day. That was really my biggest annoyance with it, otherwise I really liked a lot. Since I can't stop thinking about having it, I ordered one again to keep. 
I learned some tweaks that I can do for battery life, which I'm going to be trying immediately when I get it to see if that can extend the day a little bit more for me.
The Nextbit launcher doesn't allow custom icons.
Edit: I forgot to say that I found the Nextbit OS to be similar to "stock" (i.e. Nexus) Android, but slightly different in a good way.

I've found adding music and files from the computer to the smarphone to be very complicated in comparison to BB10 but luckily google is there to help. Any particular tips for battery usage other than not using it?  I find myself being able to keep 12-14 hours on a single charge with 3-4.5 SOT but I am running for the charger when I get home.

6 tips to improve battery life on the Nexus 5X | Android Central 
I tried that on the 5x (well, not the last tip but most of it) and it worked out well. For location, battery saving is the best mode (some people have said that they change it to high accuracy when using the maps when traveling). 
Also I turned off (Google) Now on tap in settings and that helped. You can still use it if you need it, but at least this way, it isn't always listening. 
Finally, I limited backup. In my case, I just turned it off altogether but I would think there should be a setting to reduce or change how often backup is making backups. 
It seems like a day is what someone can roughly get with the Robin, but that is what I plan to try to see how far I can extend the day.
Additionally some apps aren't so good. I hear a lot about the Facebook app being a leech around these forums. Speaking of apps, it's up to you if you want them to auto-update and install or if you want them to just notify you when updates are available.
Funny that you say running to the charger. I felt like I was doing that EVERY DAY. It made me mad. I really hope these tips help me since they helped with the 5x and the two devices are seriously similar, minus the ambient (fickle) display lol.
Edit: I keep adding to this post, sorry. I somehow forgot to say that I adjusted the "push" notifications for my email accounts. My secondary email doesn't get much email, so I set that to daily. My primary email gets email randomly, so I feel like setting that to hourly helps me. YMMV with this, you don't have to do it, it's just a suggestion.
Edit 2: The comments in the linked post are interesting, they might be worth a read. Sorry for the wall of text!

thread.text:
I just wanted to report back to say that I got my Robin and after following my own tips, I got about 20 hours on a charge including setup time off the charger. Looking forward to seeing how this plays out. Right now, I'm at 65% percent and it estimates that I have a day and 3 hours left.
I forgot that you can set wifi to not be on when the phone is sleeping. I should have tried this at work yesterday but eh, I have next week for that.
Posted via the Android Central App

Hi
If you have issues, after any major update, or security update, you should do one, or both of the options below. Hopefully the first one works for you.
1. Enter Recovery Mode, and do a Wipe of the Cache Partition. no data loss.
2. Full factory Reset - I recommend this after each update, I do, religiously. ALL DATA LOSS, PHONE AS NEW...BACKUP YOUR DEVICE.
Hope this helps!
Chris

replies.text:
I already did the first one right after the update but haven't gotten a chance to do the second. I did start backing up my stuff though in preparation.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
I surely hope if works out for you...keep us posted.
Chris

replies.text: I did a full factory reset a couple days ago. Still have the same issues so it must be an issue with the software. Guess i'll wait for the next update to be pushed.

thread.text: Overall, I like this phone. I works for me just fine and as Nextbit releases updates the phone seems to be getting better as the bugs are worked out. That being said, in the past week I have noticed that the frame seems to have warped slightly. It now rocks when laid flat on a table. I do not put my phone in my pants pockets (front or back) so the bend/warping did not come from that. The bend/warp is slight for now and I am worried that it might get worse as time goes on. Nextbit has said that the slight bend is within the margin of error for a phone with a plastic body with a metal frame. I can exchange it, but I am worried that the next phone will just do the same thing. Anyone else having issues??

replies.text: My daughter and wife seem to use snapchat a lot and I work away from home, so its a way to communicate. Also I am a huge music fan and a camera fan to some extent. I love the look of both phones, especially the robin, but LG in my mind is no slouch either. I have a ford f150 that has sync and its important that whatever phone I get will work with that. Im truly am torn on which way to go. The Robin is cheaper though, but Im from canada and our dollar is the pits...sorry I just realized I was droning on. ☺

thread.text:
I came into work this morning with a fedex box sitting on my desk. It seems to be that my phone was delivered to my over the weekend. 
Here are some quick pictures I snapped of it this morning!
Nice! Please let us know how you like it.

It feels like a great phone, sadly I don't think I'll be using it as a daily driver. I use to carry two phones when I was with my last company but I no longer use two phones. I am currently using the Nexus 6P and I don't think this will be replacing that as my daily driver. I might end up using it to tinker with or just post it up for sale for anyone who might want it. But if you'd like to see anything from the phone before I do that please let me know.

replies.text: Is it okay to ask why it can't be your daily driver? Was something not enough?

thread.text: When did you order it?

Thanks for posting those photos. I ordered one myself, I had been debating on picking up a cheap Nexus 6 or going for the Nexus 6P. Oddly enough I ended up ordering the Robin, I love the design and having a phone not everyone else has. My only concern has been the camera.
If things don't work out with it I'll end up with the 6P I'm sure.
How was battery life on the Robin?

I got mine in the midnight color. Figured I'd post some photos of it, you guys may want to see.
I really love the design and feel of the phone, for just about everything I've used it for so far it ran well. Heavy games may give it a bit of a tough time. 
My only real gripe is the camera, it's very slow to take photos. It will delay a second, almost 2 after I hit the button. Quality wise, I did some testing against a Oneplus 2 and the photos are very close, the OP2 were grainier when zoomed in, and the Robin's were less grainy but slightly more blur to them. Overall pretty good quality and pretty darn close to the OP2 photos, when not zoomed in, you can't tell much different in normal light conditions.

Just to update, I have been playing around more with the Robin, so far everything is working as expected...except the camera. I have noticed the delay between pressing the shutter and the phone actually taking the photo has varied between 1-3 seconds. This seems dependent on the amount of light when the photos are taken. (less light, longer delay)
Also, if you switch to manual camera mode and change the ISO to 100-200, the photos are much quicker. Although this doesn't work for all lighting scenarios so my feeling is this is just a software issue. I am pretty sure Nextbit is working on it from what I've read on their forums. Otherwise the camera typically takes a good photo. 
For me it's somewhat of an issue, I tried to take photos of my always on the move 2yr old and by the time the shutter went off, he was completely out of frame. I hope the fix is coming soon and significantly improves this otherwise I probably won't be using the Robin much.

thread.text:
Hey guys, 
I'm really interested the Nextbit Robin but I have some concerns that I haven't really seen clarified in any of the coverage videos I've watched. 
1.) Does the phone's custom software allow for creating folders on the homescreen for grouping apps? It seems that every time I see the phone displayed, the homescreen is just a wall of icons. 
2.) Is there no way to manually permanently delete an app? I get that the integrated cloud technology will automatically transfer apps that are rarely used or inactive after a period of time, but can you still delete an app from the Settings menu? I find that it would be pretty annoying if you dl an app that ends up being really bad or not to your liking, and then you have to keep on the phone forever. 
Anyways, those are my questions and I hope someone can help me out here. Thanks!

I'm sure you can create folders on the homescreen. That's a standard feature that many companies would receive terrible reviews for if they didn't include that. If not, you might be able to find a launcher that works with the cloud integration software.
As for the cloud integration permanent deleting, I'm sure that they will have a way to permanently delete software and its data from both the phone and the cloud.
Of course, I don't have the Nextbit Robin, but this is just probability, since the company is spending so long trying to perfect the phone (if you check out the updates on kickstarter, you'll see that they delayed it a bit to make sure it works very well, and that many checkpoints were running behind because again they wanted to perfect it)
Sorry, I just double checked the pictures. On one of the pictures, there is, in fact, a folder on the launcher.

So I got a response from Nextbit and they confirmed that you can in fact create folders and delete apps. This is good to hear because it removes the concerns I had about their custom OS possibly removing some functionality. It looks like the nextbit os will run pretty much like stock Android 6.0, but with their cloud tech integrated into the software. Good stuff!

I can confirm that you will in fact be able to create folders just like on stock Android and also delete apps right from the home screen. It will also ask if you'd like to remove it from their cloud as well.

thread.text: You guys have to remember how small this company is. They have one office in San Francisco. This isn't a worldwide brand yet.
Will the custom software be open-sourced? For custom ROM development, etc, at least for just the Robin?
Android is open source, the custom modifications normally aren't. Whether Nextbit is going to change that is something we'll just have to wait to see.

Found this quote on the website....
"No barriers.
Robin comes with an unlocked SIM, so you can choose the right carrier for you. And because we think what you run should be up to you too, we’ve made it as easy as possible for you to customize Robin. Its unlocked bootloader and open source drivers make it easy to load CyanogenMod or any other ROM you want and Robin will still be under warranty."
I really hope that means that it will at least release the apk or whatever, if not open source...
I am interested in these phones, anymore news on them?

The deadline for backer surveys is some time today, and the phones are available for preorder at nextbit.com for the public. They have a Robin working with Marshmallow running well enough for Scott Croyle to use as his daily driver. Things are still on schedule for a January deliver for early backers, so that's good. They've had another meet up in London recently where they showed off the final colors (including the backer exclusive Electric colorway), and showed off the working Robin. Up until recently they were showing the OS on a Nexus 5. In the next few weeks I believe the camera samples should be shown off. Those who have heard the audio on a non-final build say it's as loud and clear as the HTC One M8 which is impressive imo. 
Not sure how much you've been following Nextbit, so all that could be old news for you. I'll try and help with any more questions if you have them. Just ask 
Oh, one important thing: They've changed the material for the middle back piece. It was originally a plastic infused aluminum, but there were some quality control issues (I can't remember what they were now), so they switched it to a metal framed plastic.

I am interested in this phone, too. In the last month I tried 3 different phones: Moto X Pure, OnePlus X, and just recently, the Nexus 5x. I found fault with each of them, eventually favoring my OnePlus One running SlimSaber every time.
I am looking for a smaller screen size/form factor plus great ROM support. I was really hoping the 5x was going to do it for me, but I found it very laggy and would often become completely frozen. there have been a lot of reports about this, but I attribute it to the 2GB of RAM.
The Robin seems to have the same specs as the 5x, with the bonus of 3GB of RAM. Time will tell if the developer support is there. If it is, I'm going to try it. At $399 retail, I bet it will be available on swappa for a little less than that, which would make it a pretty good deal in my book. I'm a little concerned about the bottom notification LED, as there is no way to cover it up when it's on your bedside table. But there are ways to disable the LED with Do Not Disturb I believe, so maybe it will be a non-issue. I like the design/aesthetics, too. I don't care that it's plastic just hope it's not too slippery.
nope that's all new to me. I am still waiting for them to be in stock before I order. But I think my wife and I are getting two to have something different. they look great however!
I, for one, found it really interesting that they put the scanner on the side. It doesn't look as big as other phones! I'd certainly like to try it and see how it works.

replies.text: I'm hoping they share a video soon showcasing how it works compared to other phones with scanners.

thread.text: We shall see. Pretty interesting things coming out of IFA this year!
I'm honestly super interested in this phone. I'm not sure if it's b/c it looks so different or what. I'm probably gonna back it in a couple weeks before the October deadline.

replies.text:
Same here. When I get paid at the end of the month I'm getting a Midnight for me and a Mint for the wife. She's coming from a Nexus 5 and I'm coming from a G4. We both like the design and the features. And being on T-Mobile with unlimited data we have no worries about always uploading to the cloud.
Sent from my LG-H811 using Tapatalk
I ended up backing the same night I commented. So much for me waiting. Haha

Hahaha. Well I get paid at midnight. If I'm still up I'll probably back it as well.
Sent from my LG-H811 using Tapatalk

Not sure if you've checked out the comments on KS or not, but Nextbit has been interacting with the commenters answering the questions they can. They seem to be really honest and not overshooting things. I'm getting really excited.

I have checked out the comments. I can't post because I haven't backed them yet. I've asked them a few questions on Twitter, but haven't gotten a response. Yet stupid questions like "Why No Verizon?! 😖😖" get a response from them.
Sent from my LG-H811 using Tapatalk

I've noticed on the KS page if you catch em at a time they've been answering commenters recently they're good about getting back with you. There seems to be so many questions they get lost if Nextbit isn't monitoring at the time. I'm assuming it's the same on Twitter. I haven't been keeping up on there though.

thread.text:
Well I sent another question today literally 5-7 minutes after they had just answered one. Maybe my questions are stupid, or you're right there's just too many people messaging them.
Sent from my LG-H811 using Tapatalk

replies.text: If you want post your questions here and I'll ask them in the KS comments to see if I can get an answer.

It's really just stuff I can wait to find out about once the phone comes out. I asked if they were planning on doing an event in other cities, more specifically, Seattle. How the front facing speakers sounded and if there were going to be any other color options later on.
Sent from my LG-H811 using Tapatalk

In the comments they said they liked the idea of a mint and midnight mashup, but it wouldn't be for the first Robin. I know each of the ffs has it's own amp, so sound should be fairly good. I haven't seen anything on other cities yet.

Cool. Thanks man. 
Sent from my LG-H811 using Tapatalk

title: A whole new breed of phone

thread.text:
The Nextbit is offering to be a middle ground between mid and high end devices. A 32 GB storage, working in tandem with cloud storage. Priced at $400 it doesn't seem like that bad of a phone.
From the blog: Nextbit's Robin looks to merge phone and cloud like never before | Android CentralNextbit Robin specs | Android Central
I wonder who's gonna be supplying the cloud storage... If they need Kickstarter for the hardware, I'm sure running a storage service of their own would be even more costly...

replies.text:
One drive I would suspect. 
Sent from my Verizon Samsung Galaxy Note 5

thread.text: I'd assume the same people that supplied Baton will. I've never used it though, so I don't know much about it.
